item.title: Cyberpunk 2077 Update Adds Balatro Crossover Quest
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/cyberpunk-2077-update-adds-balatro-crossover-quest/1100-6528375/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

CD Projekt Red is reciprocating the love Balatro showed Cyberpunk 2077 a couple of months ago by adding a quest based on the roguelike card game. It's one of the new secrets that's now discoverable in Night City after the recent launch of Update 2.2 for the action-RPG.

The official Balatro account on X teased the crossover, showcasing that the poker-inspired game's joker mascot--named Jimbo--appears as graffiti in Cyberpunk 2077 now. That led to CD Projekt Red global PR director Radek Grabowski revealing that the collaboration is official and part of a new in-game quest.

"Some time ago, I asked the Quest Design team at CDPR: "You liked the Cyberpunk cards in Balatro? What if we had Balatro cards in Cyberpunk 2077?" Thanks to the talented quest designer Maria Mazur, we now have the Balatro quest in Update 2.2," explained Grabowski on X. "Amazing work, Maria!"

Grabowski added on X that the Cyberpunk 2077 joker found originally in Balatro as part of an update for that game is now also in the action-RPG, too. The PR director gave a shout-out to CD Projekt Red artist Olgierd Ciszak for the design.

Just like The Witcher and Cyberpunk cards in Balatro, the “Cyberpunk Joker” you can now discover in Cyberpunk 2077 as part of the Update 2.2 has been created in-house by Olgierd Ciszak - one of CDPR’s talented artists. ✨ pic.twitter.com/FzhXEaOMAH

— Radek (@gamebowski) December 11, 2024

Cyberpunk 2077 received the unexpected Update 2.2 earlier this week. The patch brings about expanded customization for cars in Night City, more rides to collect, an overhauled photo mode, and more.

Previously, Cyberpunk 2077 almost had a Witcher 3 crossover that could have seen Geralt of Rivia in Night City. Meanwhile, CD Projekt Red has confirmed that a PS5 Pro patch isn't happening for Cyberpunk 2077.

For more, check out GameSpot's Cyberpunk 2077: Phantom Liberty review.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Red Dead Actor Rob Wiethoff Starts An OnlyFans For Getting Ripped
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/red-dead-actor-rob-wiethoff-starts-an-onlyfans-for-getting-ripped/1100-6528373/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Actor Rob Wiethoff famously portrayed John Marston in Rockstar's acclaimed 2010 Red Dead Redemption, and now he's starting a new project that is completely different and unexpected. Wiethoff, 48, has launched an OnlyFans, but it's not that kind of OnlyFans. After fans discovered he had an OnlyFans set up, Wietoff released a video responding to what he described as "panic" surrounding this.

"I have an OnlyFans page. I do," Wietoff told his 200,000 followers on Instagram in a video address. It costs $5/month to subscribe. Wiethoff's OnlyFans account will be focused on his own personal health journey as he looks to get lean and ripped.

"There will be nothing but me trying to get in shape. If you want to be part of that, you are welcome to join," he said. "I know what OnlyFans is. Not everything on there has to be that kind of content. That is not what my content is going to be. If you want to get ripped with an old-timer, sign up; that's it."

In addition to voicing John Marston in the original Red Dead, Wiethoff came back to play the character once again in Red Dead Redemption II, which is a prequel to the first game.

In other Red Dead news, the original game finally came to PC earlier this year with its Undead Nightmare expansion. Rockstar Games is now working on Grand Theft Auto VI, which is set for release in Fall 2025. However, reporter Jason Schreier said this week that he would be "shocked" if the game isn't delayed to 2026.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Pokemon And Wallace & Gromit Studio Teaming Up For New Project Due In 2027
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/pokemon-and-wallace-gromit-studio-teaming-up-for-new-project-due-in-2027/1100-6528371/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Pokemon and Aardman are teaming up for... something. The two companies announced a partnership today, saying whatever they're making together is coming in 2027.

A teaser image showed a Poke Ball forming with Aardman's trademark clay for its claymation animation style (and no, there is no clay shortage). One guess here would be that Aardman is producing a Pokemon TV show or movie with its trademark animation style, but that's just speculation.

In a statement, Aardman said it's working with The Pokemon Company on a "special project coming to audiences in 2027." This project, whatever it is, will retain Aardman's trademark style in the Pokemon universe with "brand-new adventures."

An iconinc UK animation studio, Aardman is best known for the Wallace & Gromit and Chicken Run franchises. Its parternship with The Pokemon Company isn't the only licensed project it has in the works, as Aardman is also working with Mattel on a Pingu reboot TV series.

In October this year, Aardman announced layoffs after losing more than $700,000 in 2023. Aardman's next big release is Wallace & Gromit: Vengeance Most Fowl, which releases on Christmas Day on BBC and then on January 3, 2025 on Netflix.

As for the Pokemon game series, the next big release is Pokemon Legends: Z-A, which comes to Nintendo Switch in 2025. The latest Pokemon sensation is the mobile game Pokemon Trading Card Game Pocket, which is estimated to have already earned more than $200 million in revenue.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Lucasfilm Says It Would Be "Super Interesting" To Make More Indiana Jones Games
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/lucasfilm-says-it-would-be-super-interesting-to-make-more-indiana-jones-games/1100-6528369/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle is out now on PC and Xbox, but could MachineGames come back for a sequel or a different Indiana Jones game in the future? It's too soon to say, but Lucasfilm Games executive Douglas Reilly told Variety the team is "always looking for great stories." He stopped short of saying if MachineGames or another studio could make a new Indiana Jones game, however.

"Right now, we're focused on getting this one to the public and getting to the DLC and making this as successful as we can," Reilly said of the game and its upcoming The Order of Giants expansion. "I think we're always looking for great stories. And the good news is, there's a lot of space in between the films where we could tell more and more Indiana Jones stories that I think would be super interesting."

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle - Official Launch Trailer

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

The Great Circle is a single-player adventure game that takes place between the events of Raiders of the Lost Ark and The Last Crusade, in the year 1937. Players take on the iconic role of Indiana Jones as they try to stop evil forces from obtaining a power known as The Great Circle.

There have been lots of Indiana Jones video games over the years, and The Great Circle is the first title for console since Lego Indiana Jones 2 in 2011.

Also in the interview, Reilly shared more insight on how Lucasfilm interacts with game developers working on its properties. "We don't tell the teams how to run development. We don't tell them how to run their day-to-day of the business," he said.

For The Great Circle, Lucasfilm was involved in making sure the game "looks, feels, [and] sounds like Indiana Jones," and that included approving the casting of Troy Baker as Indiana Jones himself.

"Between the work MachineGames did in representing him physically and the absolutely stunning work Troy has done voicing the character, you forget it's not Harrison when you play it. He's that good," Reilly said.

Whether or not another Indiana Jones game from MachineGames or anyone else gets made likely has to do, in part, with the commercial success of The Great Circle. Microsoft doesn't typically announce sales numbers, and the fact that The Great Circle is also on Game Pass doesn't make it easy to understand how the game is performing. On Steam, The Great Circle is listed as a top-seller and has reached 12,000 concurrent players there. It is not inside the top 500 games on Xbox's top paid games list, but there are plenty of reasons for why this could be.

The Great Circle began development prior to Microsoft's acquisition of MachineGames via its buyout of parent company ZeniMax. Making The Great Circle exclusive to Xbox at launch is expected to amount to millions in lost sales, Microsoft has said. The Great Circle is scheduled to come to PS5 in Spring 2025.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
